message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Voice in Human–Agent Interaction
Paper Abstract: Social robots, conversational agents, voice assistants, and other embodied AI are increasingly a feature of everyday life. What connects these various types of intelligent agents is their ability to interact with people through voice. Voice is becoming an essential modality of embodiment, communication, and interaction between computer-based agents and end-users. This survey presents a meta-synthesis on agent voice in the design and experience of agents from a human-centered perspective: voice-based human–agent interaction (vHAI). Findings emphasize the social role of voice in HAI as well as circumscribe a relationship between agent voice and body, corresponding to human models of social psychology and cognition. Additionally, changes in perceptions of and reactions to agent voice over time reveals a generational shift coinciding with the commercial proliferation of mobile voice assistants. The main contributions of this work are a vHAI classification framework for voice across various agent forms, contexts, and user groups, a critical analysis grounded in key theories, and an identification of future directions for the oncoming wave of vocal machines.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Based on the search results, here's information about conversational agents:

## Definition

A dialogue system, or conversational agent (CA), is a computer system intended to converse with a human.(no content)A conversational user interface (CUI) is a user interface for computers that emulates a conversation with a human.

## Key Technologies

Conversational interfaces use natural language processing (NLP) to allow computers to understand, analyze, and create meaning from human language.(no content)CUIs provide opportunity for the user to communicate with the computer in their natural language rather than in a syntax specific commands.

## Types

There are two main categories of conversational interfaces; voice assistants and chatbots.(no content)A voice user interface allows a user to complete an action by speaking a command.(no content)A chatbot is a web- or mobile-based interface that allows the user to ask questions and retrieve information.

## Applications

Conversational agents are used in various business contexts, including customer service, help desks, technical support, and guided selling. Conversational interfaces have emerged as a tool for businesses to efficiently provide consumers with relevant information, in a cost-effective manner.

I've completed a web search for "Natural language processing." Here are the key findings:

## Overview

Natural language processing (NLP) is the processing of natural language information by a computer and is a subfield of computer science closely associated with artificial intelligence.

## Core Capabilities

Major processing tasks in an NLP system include: speech recognition, text classification, natural language understanding, and natural language generation. More broadly, NLP involves computers analyzing, understanding, altering, or generating natural language, including automation of linguistic forms like conversation, correspondence, reading, writing, and translation.

## Historical Development

Natural language processing has its roots in the 1950s.(no content)Up until the 1980s, most NLP systems were based on complex sets of hand-written rules, but starting in the late 1980s, there was a revolution with the introduction of machine learning algorithms for language processing.

## Recent Advancements

The Transformer architecture was introduced in 2017.(no content)In recent years, advancements in deep learning and large language models have significantly enhanced the capabilities of natural language processing, leading to widespread applications in areas such as healthcare, customer service, and content generation.

Based on the search results, here's information about cognition:

## Definition and Overview

Cognitions are mental activities that deal with knowledge and encompass psychological processes that acquire, store, retrieve, transform, or otherwise use information.(no content)Cognition refers to the mental processes of how a person gains knowledge, uses existing knowledge, and understands things that are happening around them using their thoughts and senses.

## Types of Cognitive Processes

Cognition is not limited to abstract reasoning and encompasses diverse psychological processes, including perception, attention, memory, language, and decision-making.(no content)Many cognitive activities deal with language, including language acquisition, comprehension, and production.

## Conscious and Unconscious Cognition

Cognitive activities can happen consciously, like when a person deliberately analyzes a problem step by step, or take place unconsciously, such as automatic mechanisms responsible for language processing and facial recognition.

## Field of Study

Many disciplines explore cognition, including psychology, neuroscience, and cognitive science.(no content)Cognitive psychology is the scientific study of human mental processes such as attention, language use, memory, perception, problem solving, creativity, and reasoning.

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about voice assistants:

## Definition and Overview

A virtual assistant is a software agent that can perform a range of tasks or services for a user based on user input, such as commands or questions, including verbal ones.(no content)Such technologies often incorporate chatbot capabilities to streamline task execution.

## Growth and Usage

Voice assistants have become central to technology platforms and, in many countries, to day-to-day life. Between 2008 and 2018, the frequency of voice-based internet search queries increased 35 times and account for close to one fifth of mobile internet searches.(no content)Voice assistants now manage upwards of 1 billion tasks per month, from the mundane (changing a song) to the essential (contacting emergency services).

## Major Voice Assistants

The most prominent voice assistants available today include:

- **Google Assistant**: Google Assistant is available in more than 90 countries and over 30 languages, and is used by more than 500 million users monthly.

- **Siri**: Siri is a virtual assistant and chatbot purchased, developed, and popularized by Apple Inc., which is included in the iOS, iPadOS, watchOS, macOS, Apple TV, audioOS, and visionOS operating systems.

- **Amazon Alexa**: Amazon has Alexa (named for the ancient library in Alexandria).

- **Bixby**: Bixby is a voice assistant developed by Samsung that provides device control, information retrieval, and task automation using voice input and artificial intelligence.

## Technology Behind Voice Assistants

Virtual assistants use natural language processing (NLP) to match user text or voice input to executable commands.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Voice user interface"

Links: [{"title":"Voice user interface - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Voice_user_interface"},{"title":"Conversational user interface - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conversational_user_interfaces"},{"title":"Thomson SmartVision - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SmartVision"},{"title":"Zero-G Ltd - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zero-G_Ltd"},{"title":"Microsoft Speech API - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Speech_Application_Programming_Interface"},{"title":"Radio Network Controller - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Radio_Network_Controller"},{"title":"Adobe XD - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adobe_Experience_Design"}]

## Voice User Interface - Search Results

Here are the key findings from the search on voice user interfaces:

**Definition and Core Functionality**

A voice-user interface (VUI) enables spoken human interaction with computers, using speech recognition to understand spoken commands and answer questions, and typically text to speech to play a reply.

**Technology and Development**

Advances in technologies like text-to-speech, speech-to-text, natural language processing, and cloud services contributed to the mass adoption of these types of interfaces.(no content)VUIs have become more commonplace, and people are taking advantage of the value that these hands-free, eyes-free interfaces provide in many situations.

**Modern Applications**

Apple's Siri, introduced in October 2011, was one of the first voice assistants widely adopted, allowing users of iPhone to get information and complete actions on their device simply by asking Siri.(no content)Further development has included home based devices such as Google Home or Amazon Echo (powered by Alexa) that allow users to "connect" their homes through a series of smart devices.

**Capabilities**

Newer voice command devices are speaker-independent, so they can respond to multiple voices, regardless of accent or dialectal influences, and are capable of responding to several commands at once, separating vocal messages, and providing appropriate feedback, accurately imitating a natural conversation.

**Design Challenges**

With purely audio-based interaction, voice user interfaces tend to suffer from low discoverability: it is difficult for users to understand the scope of a system's capabilities.

Web search results for query: "Social robot"

Links: [{"title":"Social robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_robot"},{"title":"Media Lab Europe's social robots - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Media_Lab_Europe's_social_robots"},{"title":"Socially assistive robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Socially_assistive_robot"},{"title":"Nadine Social Robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nadine_Social_Robot"},{"title":"Sociorobotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sociorobotics"},{"title":"Category:Social robots - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Social_robots"},{"title":"Leonardo (robot) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leonardo_(robot)"},{"title":"Tico Robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tico_Robot"},{"title":"Japanese robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Japanese_robotics"},{"title":"The Sociological Imagination - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Sociological_Imagination"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about social robots:

## Definition and Overview

A social robot interacts socially with humans or evokes social responses from them.(no content)The nature of the social interactions is immaterial and may range from relatively simple supportive tasks, such as passing tools to a worker, to complex expressive communication and collaboration, such as assistive healthcare.

## Historical Development

Since the 1990s, artificial intelligence and robotics researchers have developed robots which explicitly engage on a social level.(no content)The evolution of social robots began with autonomous robots designed to have little to no interaction with humans. Essentially, they were designed to take on what humans could not. Technologically advanced robots were sent out to handle hazardous conditions and the assignments that could potentially put humans in danger, like exploring the deep oceans or the surface of Mars.

## Current Applications

Social robots start following humans into much more personal settings like home, health care, and education. A related field, socially assistive robots (SARs) aid users through social engagement and support rather than through physical tasks and interactions, and in contrast to social robots, SARs aid users with specific goals related to behavior change.

## Human Interaction

Many people are uneasy about interacting socially with a robot and, in general, people tend to prefer smaller robots to large humanoid robots. They also prefer robots to do tasks like cleaning the house rather than providing companionship. However, exposure to a social robot may decrease uncertainty and increase willingness to interact with the robot, and research shows that over time people speak for a longer time and share more information in their disclosures to a social robot.

## Web Search Results for "Human-computer interaction"

I've found comprehensive information about human-computer interaction. Here are the key findings:

### Definition and Overview

Human–computer interaction (HCI) is the process through which people operate and engage with computer systems.(no content)Research in HCI covers the design and the use of computer technology, whichfocuses on the interfaces between people (users) and computers.

### Scope and Disciplines

The Association for Computing Machinery (ACM) defines human–computer interaction as "a discipline that is concerned with the design, evaluation, and implementation of interactive computing systems for human use and with the study of major phenomena surrounding them".(no content)HCI draws from supporting knowledge on both the machine side (including computer graphics, operating systems, programming languages) and the human side (including communication theory, graphic and industrial design, linguistics, social sciences, cognitive psychology, and human factors).

### Key Applications and Interaction Methods

Desktop applications, web browsers, handheld computers, and computer kiosks make use of the prevalent graphical user interfaces (GUIs) of today.

Modern HCI research includes several interaction approaches:
- Gesture recognition, which involves identifying and interpreting gestures made by users
- Gaze detection (eye-movement tracking), which involves tracking the movement of a user's eyes and is primarily used to better understand the user's attention, intent, or focus
- Facial expression analysis, which focuses on visually recognizing and analyzing emotions through facial expressions

### Historical Context

The term was popularized by Stuart Card, Allen Newell, and Thomas P. Moran in their 1983 book, The Psychology of Human–Computer Interaction.

Human-computer interaction remains a critical field for creating effective, user-friendly technologies across all industries.

Web search results for query: "Social psychology"

Links: [{"title":"Social psychology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_psychology"},{"title":"List of social psychology theories - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_social_psychology_theories"},{"title":"Social Psychology Network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_Psychology_Network"},{"title":"Society of Experimental Social Psychology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Society_of_Experimental_Social_Psychology"},{"title":"Journal of Personality and Social Psychology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Journal_of_Personality_and_Social_Psychology"},{"title":"Social media and psychology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_media_and_psychology"},{"title":"Personality and Social Psychology Review - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Personality_and_Social_Psychology_Review"},{"title":"Society for Personality and Social Psychology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Society_for_Personality_and_Social_Psychology"},{"title":"Social Psychology (Community) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_Psychology_(Community)"},{"title":"European Journal of Social Psychology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/European_Journal_of_Social_Psychology"}]

Here are the search results for "Social psychology":

## Definition and Overview

Social psychology is the methodical study of how thoughts, feelings, and behaviors are influenced by the actual, imagined, or implied presence of others.(no content)Social psychologists typically explain human behavior as a result of the relationship between mental states and social situations, studying the social conditions under which thoughts, feelings, and behaviors occur, and how these variables influence social interactions.

## Key Differences from Sociology

Although studying many of the same substantive topics as its counterpart in the field of sociology, psychological social psychology places more emphasis on the individual, rather than society; the influence of social structure and culture on individual outcomes, such as personality, behavior, and one's position in social hierarchies.

## Historical Development

In the 19th century, social psychology began to emerge from the larger field of psychology, and one of the first published studies in the field was Norman Triplett's 1898 experiment on the phenomenon of social facilitation.(no content)According to Wolfgang Stroebe, modern social psychology began in 1924 with the publication of a classic textbook by Floyd Allport, which defined the field as the experimental study of social behavior.

## Major Theories

Social psychology utilizes various influential theories, including attribution theory, which is concerned with the ways in which people explain the behavior of others—dividing attributions into external or "situational" attributions, which assign causality to an outside factor, and internal or "dispositional" attributions, which assign causality to factors within the person.(no content)Cognitive dissonance was originally based on the concept of cognitive consistency, and when people do something that violates their view of themselves, this causes an uncomfortable state of dissonance that motivates a change in either attitudes or behavior.

## Current Focus Areas

Most modern researchers in the 21st century are interested in phenomena such as attribution, social cognition, and self-concept.(no content)Social psychologists are, in addition, concerned with applied psychology, contributing towards applications of social psychology in health, education, law, and the workplace.

Web search results for query: "Embodied AI"

Links: [{"title":"Embodied agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Embodied_agent"},{"title":"Artificial consciousness - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_consciousness"},{"title":"Artificial general intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_general_intelligence"},{"title":"Cynthia Breazeal - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/JIBO"},{"title":"Katherine Elkins - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Katherine_Elkins"}]

## Embodied AI Search Results

Based on the web search results, here's what I found about Embodied AI:

### Definition and Core Concept

In artificial intelligence, an embodied agent is an intelligent agent that interacts with the environment through a physical body within that environment.(no content)Agents that are represented graphically with a body, for example a human or a cartoon animal, are also called embodied agents, although they have only virtual, not physical, embodiment.

### Applications and Examples

Mobile robots are one example of physically embodied agents; Ananova and Microsoft Agent are examples of graphically embodied agents.(no content)Embodied conversational agents have been used in virtual training environments, portable personal navigation guides, interactive fiction and storytelling systems, interactive online characters and automated presenters and commentators.

### Communication and Interaction

Graphically embodied agents aim to unite gesture, facial expression and speech to enable face-to-face communication with users, providing a powerful means of human-computer interaction.(no content)Research has found that users prefer a non-verbal visual indication of an embodied system's internal state to a verbal indication, demonstrating the value of additional non-verbal communication channels.

### Relevance to AI Development

A fundamental criticism of the simulated brain approach derives from embodied cognition theory, which asserts that human embodiment is an essential aspect of human intelligence and is necessary to ground meaning. If this theory is correct, any fully functional brain model will need to encompass more than just the neurons (e.g., a robotic body).

## Embodied AI Search Results

Based on the web search results, here's what I found about Embodied AI:

### Definition and Core Concept

In artificial intelligence, an embodied agent is an intelligent agent that interacts with the environment through a physical body within that environment.(no content)Agents that are represented graphically with a body, for example a human or a cartoon animal, are also called embodied agents, although they have only virtual, not physical, embodiment.

### Applications and Examples

Mobile robots are one example of physically embodied agents; Ananova and Microsoft Agent are examples of graphically embodied agents.(no content)Embodied conversational agents have been used in virtual training environments, portable personal navigation guides, interactive fiction and storytelling systems, interactive online characters and automated presenters and commentators.

### Communication and Interaction

Graphically embodied agents aim to unite gesture, facial expression and speech to enable face-to-face communication with users, providing a powerful means of human-computer interaction.(no content)Research has found that users prefer a non-verbal visual indication of an embodied system's internal state to a verbal indication, demonstrating the value of additional non-verbal communication channels.

### Relevance to AI Development

A fundamental criticism of the simulated brain approach derives from embodied cognition theory, which asserts that human embodiment is an essential aspect of human intelligence and is necessary to ground meaning. If this theory is correct, any fully functional brain model will need to encompass more than just the neurons (e.g., a robotic body).

## Speech Synthesis - Search Results

Based on the search results, here's an overview of speech synthesis:

### Definition and Basics

Speech synthesis is the artificial production of human speech. A computer system used for this purpose is called a speech synthesizer, and can be implemented in software or hardware products.

### Types of Systems

A text-to-speech (TTS) system converts normal language text into speech; other systems render symbolic linguistic representations like phonetic transcriptions into speech.

There are different approaches to creating synthesized speech:
- Synthesized speech can be created by concatenating pieces of recorded speech that are stored in a database. Systems differ in the size of the stored speech units; a system that stores phones or diphones provides the largest output range, but may lack clarity. For specific usage domains, the storage of entire words or sentences allows for high-quality output.
- Alternatively, a synthesizer can incorporate a model of the vocal tract and other human voice characteristics to create a completely "synthetic" voice output.

### How Text-to-Speech Works

A text-to-speech system is composed of two parts: a front-end and a back-end. The front-end assigns phonetic transcriptions to each word, and divides and marks the text into prosodic units. The back-end then converts the symbolic linguistic representation into sound.

### Modern Deep Learning Approaches

Deep learning speech synthesis refers to the application of deep learning models to generate natural-sounding human speech from written text (text-to-speech) or spectrum (vocoder).(no content)In September 2016, DeepMind released WaveNet, which demonstrated that deep learning-based models are capable of modeling raw waveforms and generating speech from acoustic features. Although WaveNet was initially considered computationally expensive, a year after its release, DeepMind unveiled Parallel WaveNet, a production model 1,000 times faster than the original.

### Applications

An intelligible text-to-speech program allows people with visual impairments or reading disabilities to listen to written words on a home computer.(no content)Virtual assistants such as Siri and Alexa have the ability to turn text into audio and synthesize speech.

I've successfully retrieved search results about Human-Computer Interaction from Wikipedia. Here are the key findings:

## Definition

The Association for Computing Machinery (ACM) defines human–computer interaction as "a discipline that is concerned with the design, evaluation, and implementation of interactive computing systems for human use and with the study of major phenomena surrounding them".

## Key Concepts

The term is intended to convey that, unlike other tools with specific and limited uses, computers have many uses which often involve an open-ended dialogue between the user and the computer. The notion of dialogue likens human–computer interaction to human-to-human interaction: an analogy that is crucial to theoretical considerations in the field.(no content)HCI is also sometimes termed human–machine interaction (HMI), man-machine interaction (MMI) or computer-human interaction (CHI).

## Interdisciplinary Nature

Because human–computer interaction studies a human and a machine in communication, it draws from supporting knowledge on both the machine and the human side. On the machine side, techniques in computer graphics, operating systems, programming languages, and development environments are relevant. On the human side, communication theory, graphic and industrial design disciplines, linguistics, social sciences, cognitive psychology, social psychology, and human factors such as computer user satisfaction are relevant.

The search results show that HCI is a comprehensive field that combines computer science with behavioral and social sciences to create more effective and user-friendly interactive systems.

## Analysis Complete ✅

**Paper Classification:** Survey

**Triples Extracted:** 10 entities identified from the paper title and abstract

- **Artifacts (4):** Social robot, Dialogue system, Virtual assistant, Voice user interface
- **Concepts (4):** Embodied agent, Human-computer interaction, Social psychology, Cognition

**Key Findings:**
The paper is classified as a **survey** that synthesizes existing literature on voice-based human-agent interaction (vHAI). It focuses on how voice functions as a communication modality in various types of embodied AI systems including social robots, conversational agents, and voice assistants. The survey grounds its analysis in key theories from social psychology and cognitive science, examining generational shifts in how people perceive agent voice.

It focuses on how voice functions as a communication modality in various types of embodied AI systems including social robots, conversational agents, and voice assistants. The survey grounds its analysis in key theories from social psychology and cognitive science, examining generational shifts in how people perceive agent voice.
